citeinfo.origin: Northwest Fisheries Science Center (NWFSC), National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)
citeinfo.title: A Study of the Ocean Migrations of Sockeye Salmon and Estimation of the Carrying-Capacity of the North Pacific Ocean Using a Dynamical Salmon Ecosystem Model (NOPASA)

abstract.p: This report describes the use of NOAPASA to determine the average seasonal movements of salmon in the ocean as affected by currents and water temperature, and to determine weather the ocean food resources might be limiting salmon production. The North Pacific Salmon simulation model (NOPASA) is a numerical simulation, based on available quantitative data and knowledge of processes. The NOPASA I deals mainly with sockeye, although the carrying capacity of the North Pacific is computed using all species of Pacific salmon.

[Reference: FAVORITE, F., and T. LAEVASTU. 1979. A study of the ocean migrations of sockeye salmon and estimation of the carrying-capacity of the North Pacific Ocean using a Dynamical Salmon Ecosystem Model (NOPASA). NWAFC Processed Rep. 79-16, 47 p. Northwest and Alaska Fish. Cent., Natl. Mar. Fish. Serv., NOAA, 7600 Sand Point Way NE, Seattle, WA 98115-0070.]

descript.purpose: To simulate in space and time of oceanic migrations of sockeye salmon.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system.
